This free family event features artisans, crafters, street performers and live musical entertainment, weather permitting. At Clearwater Beach’s Pier 60, the nightly sunset celebration resumes Search query Search the web Skip to main News Finance Sports More -1 Manage your account Help Add or switch accounts Sign out Search the web Advertisement Advertisement Return to Homepage Top Stories: Charlie Kirk fatally shot Who was Charlie Kirk? Ellison surpasses Musk Pandemic pups Trump on N.C. train stabbing Harris on Biden's decision to run Trump barred from firing Lisa Cook Trump: Epstein note a 'dead issue' 2 Americans fly to Tunisia by mistake 'Phillies Karen' viral drama Tampa Bay Times, St. Petersburg, Fla. At Clearwater Beach’s Pier 60, the nightly sunset celebration resumes Nicolas Villamil, Tampa Bay Times Fri, June 20, 2025 at 9:30 AM UTC 4 min read At Clearwater Beach’s Pier 60, the nightly sunset celebration resumes Yahoo is using AI to generate takeaways from this article. This means the info may not always match what's in the article. Reporting mistakes helps us improve the experience. Generate Key Takeaways Nine months after hurricanes Helene and Milton ravaged Clearwater Beach’s Pier 60, regulars are striving for pre-storm normalcy — and to an extent, achieving it. Beachgoers from near and far have returned, and so have the vendors and performers. They make up the lifeblood of the pier’s nightly sunset celebration, a showcase of art and busking which dates back three decades. With rainbow umbrellas at their backs, artisans line the pier, greeting those who wander to their tables from nearby hotels and the sand. As another storm season begins, those who rely on the gathering for their livelihood are still feeling anxious. Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Lisa Chandler, a lifelong Clearwater resident who has coordinated the nonprofit Sunsets at Pier 60 with her husband Steve since 1995, said last summer’s storms were unprecedented for the area. “In at least my history of being a business owner on Clearwater Beach, nothing has ever compared to the magnitude of what we experienced last summer,” said Chandler, who owns Pier 60 Concessions and the Barefoot Beach House restaurant on the southern end of the barrier island. Most devastating, Chandler said, was the storm surge from Hurricane Helene. The Barefoot Beach House took on about 5 feet of water, and when Chandler and her husband visited afterward, kitchen equipment like fryers and commercial freezers were gone. Chandler believes they are lost in the gulf. “Everything inside the building was basically sucked out,” said Chandler, 54. Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement The storm surge scattered the beach’s famed sugar sands and debris onto roads. Sunsets at Pier 60 could not return until the city cleared the roads, decontaminated the sand and replaced parts of the beach where the shoreline was left thin. Crews used the pier’s parking as a hub, Chandler said. While that played out, the pier’s animating characters were in limbo. Sunsets at Pier 60 started up again in mid-November, but the festivities were limited to the base of the main attraction, the pier, until it reopened Feb. 28. “We were really nervous that they were gonna shut down for good,” said Hailey Hasseltine, 29. She quit her job selling life insurance a year ago to launch a stand where customers can pick a pearl out of an oyster. Jeannie Young, a Clearwater mother who has been selling her handmade yarn creations for four years on Pier 60, said the hurricanes hindered her financially. Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement “It was concerning,” Young, 43, said of the seven weeks away from the pier. “Last year was hard. We cut back on spending as a family to get through it.” Michelle Quigley has sold Zen gardens, wooden coasters and candles with gemstone bases at the pier for two years. She said she was grateful to return in November but that sales are better now that she can set up on the pier. Quigley, 53, who lives in Tarpon Springs, is among the artisans who rely on sales as their sole income. She said she typically works five days a week at the pier and relies on it as her “bread and butter,” though she also sells online and wholesale. Last year’s hurricanes marked the end for some at the pier because they could not afford to wait to return. Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement “Some vendors had to get a regular day job,” Young said. “A lot of vendors went and looked at other weekend events … and that’s where they’re staying.” Problems persist for some who returned. Under their displays, merchants conceal the expensive generators they bought because electricity has not been restored at the pier. After about two months of not being able to work, this proved to be an unwelcome expense. And while the pier is drawing crowds, festival veterans estimate they are smaller. Nearby construction at the Clearwater Beach Marina limits access to a sidewalk that serves as an important pathway from hotels to the pier. The work is not slated to be completed until August 2026 . Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Pier 60 has still not opened beyond the bait shop, which is located about two-thirds of the way down the pier. The remaining third of the pier is a popular fishing and sightseeing spot with a separating revolving door visitors must pay to walk past. Access fees and bait shop sales brought in nearly $2 million in revenue in each of the last two years, Clearwater’s assistant director of parks and recreation Matthew Anderson told the City Council earlier this month. Three days later, the council authorized a contract worth more than $300,000 to a Dunedin-based construction company for repairs to the bait house and temporary repairs to the pier. With a reopening date of Sept. 1, Anderson estimates nearly an entire year of revenue has been lost since Helene. For now, the festivities and camaraderie at Clearwater’s most iconic landmark feel a far cry from last year’s scenes of destruction. A feeling of warmth has returned to Pier 60, and not only from the humidity and the buskers who perform daring acts with flames. But as another hurricane season begins, Lisa Chandler can’t help but keep memories of the last one front of mind. “Having experienced what we went through this past year, I will personally be more in tune to every storm.“ Chandler said. “But Mother Nature and the storm surge? Definitely not to be underestimated.” Advertisement About Our Ads Solve the daily Crossword 22,504 people played the daily Crossword recently. Clearwater Beach The activities at Pier 60 Clearwater Beach include the daily Sunset Festivals, the Sunset Cinema Movies, street performers, crafters, food vendors, people watching, and more. Pier 60 is a great place to spend an afternoon or evening. It is located right in the heart of Clearwater Beach near the roundabout. Daily Sunset Festival - The Sunsets at Pier 60 Daily Festival operates 364 days a year from two hours before sunset until two hours after sunset, weather permitting.  When you go you will see artisans, crafters, street performers, and the world famous Pier 60 sunsets over the Gulf of Mexico. Street Performers - One of our favorite things is to watch the Street Performing.  There’s no telling who will show up on any given night, but we have seen some really talented people who enthralled the audience. There is no admission fee and no tickets sold, but the performers are not shy about asking for a well-deserved donation at the end in a nice way. Crafters - There is usually a good assortment of crafters selling their wares. It’s interesting stuff and the vendors are always happy to talk to you. You can usually find a unique gift to take home the family or loved ones. The crafters typically include braids and wraps, photography, makeup, paintings, artwork, jewelry, nautical items, candles, gift items, and much more. Fishing Pier - There is also the fishing pier which reaches out over a thousand feet into the Gulf of Mexico. You can walk part of the pier near the shoreline but there is a fee to go out to the end. It depends a lot on the season and tides, but the common fish that are caught include Spanish mackerel, trout, snook, redfish, tarpon, sheepshead, snappers, flounder, jacks and more. We hope you enjoyed this write-up about one of our favorite beach spots, Clearwater Beach Pier 60. If you have any questions or need help in any way please give us a call at 727-619-2799 .
